definition: to take up an official post

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
to serve as an official/an official/the two chess pieces in Chinese chess guarding the "general" or "king" 將|将[jiang4]

sentences.english: Thought , aspiration that judging from Confucian learning, he has to go into the society actively become an official.
sentences.chinese: 从儒家思想上看，他有积极入世的思想，渴望出仕。

sentences.english: In ancient times most scholars' main pursuits were to become government officials.
sentences.chinese: 在古代，出仕为官是大多数文人的追求。

definition: to take an official post/to become a government employee
to resign a government post
(literary) to serve as an official
imperial examination
to retire from a government post (old)
to propose (for a job)/to nominate/to recommend
scholarly honor (in imperial exams)/rank/achievement/fame/glory
xiaolian, two examination subjects in Han, later a single subject in Ming and Qing/successful second degree candidate
successful candidate in the highest imperial civil service examination/palace graduate
scholar
to have reached the highest official positions
graduate/successful candidate in the imperial provincial examination
to pass an exam
to dismiss from office/to resign from office
official career (formal)
to confer a title/to ennoble/to knight/title of nobility
